update.body:
Okay, quick confessions:

1. I was sent this book in proof. I've since purchased it, but yes, I was given a copy by the publisher. Consider me blandished.

2. Erin has just blurbed (wonderfully) for Angelmaker, which raises the spectre of this being a sort of incestuous quid pro ...more...

update.body: I'm 68% through it in one day so far! I feel bad because it's beautiful outside and I've been sitting on the couch reading all day.

gave 3 stars to: American Pastoral (Paperback) by Philip Roth
is 80% done with Angelica

author.about:
I’ve been writing stories and poems since I was eight years old. My first poem was about Halloween: "What is tonight? What is tonight?/Try to guess and you’ll guess right." Perhaps this inauspicious beginning explains why it took me till I was in my thirties to sell a novel. It occurred to me early on that it might take some time and a lot of tries before I was able to publish any of my creative writing, so I pursued a degree in journalism at Northwestern University so I’d be able to support myself while I figured out how to write fiction.
I’ve spent most of my journalism career at three trade and association magazines—The Professional Photographer (which, as you might guess, went to studio and industrial photographers), DECOR (which went to frame shop and art gallery owners), and BizEd (which is directed at deans and professors at business schools). My longest stint, seventeen years, was at DECOR. Many people don’t know this, but I’m a CPF (Certified Picture Framer), having passed a very long, technical test to prove I understood the tenets of conservation framing. Now I write about management education and interview some really cool, really smart people from all over the world.
I mostly write my fiction in the evenings and on weekends. It requires a pretty obsessive-compulsive personality to be as prolific as I’ve been in the past ten years and hold down a full-time job. But I do manage to tear myself away from the computer now and then to do something fun. I read as often as I can, across all genres, though I’m most often holding a book that’s fantasy or romance, with the occasional western thrown in. I’m a fan of Cardinals baseball and try to be at the ballpark on opening day. If I had the time, I’d see a movie every day of my life. I love certain TV shows so much that knowing a new episode is going to air that night will make me happy all day. (I’m a huge Joss Whedon fan, but in the past I’ve given my heart to shows all over the map in terms of quality: "Knight Rider," "Remington Steele," "Blake’s 7," "Moonlighting," "The Young Riders," "Cheers," "Hill Street Blues," "X-Files," "Lost," "Battlestar Galactica"...you can probably fill in the gaps. And let’s not forget my very first loves, "The Partridge Family," "Here Come the Brides" and "Alias Smith & Jones.")
I don’t have kids, I don’t want pets, and all my plants die, so I’m really only forced to provide ongoing care for my menagerie of stuffed animals. All my friends are animal lovers, though, and someone once theorized that I keep friends as pets. I’m still trying to decide if that’s true.
author.name: Sharon Shinn

update.body:
I'm loving this. Taken in tandem with Lewis's previous book, The Big Short, it's a hilarious and terrifying explanation of the present financial crisis (ruination, collapse, armageddon?)

I was chatting to a couple of people the other day who really know finance and suchlike, and they object...more...

update.action_text: gave 5 stars to: The Sisters Brothers (Hardcover) by Patrick deWitt
update.body:
I loved this book. I'm exhausted and a bit frazzled so if I don't clearly express why, I'm sorry. But:

The language has a poetic, restrained quality which mingles wit and sorrow and expresses the identity of the narrator elegantly without ever becoming intrusive. The story - a strange, wayw...more...

gave 4 stars to: Ready Player One (Hardcover) by Ernest Cline
update.body: I burned through this one in a couple of days, dragged along by the action. It's huge fun, and a really intriguing portrait of a world living mostly in simulation. It goes from fantasy world to grim reality in seconds, occasionally landing a real cognitive one-two punch straight on your thinking par...more...

update.action_text: gave 4 stars to: Fire Star (The Last Dragon Chronicles, #3) by Chris d'Lacey
update.body: Even though I read this book out of order and there was a lot of backstory that I didn't know, I still really liked it. I would compare it to Eragon and I liked Eragon as well. I would actually like to read the other books in this series and just haven't gotten around to it yet.

update.action_text: gave 3 stars to: The Lost Book of Enoch (Paperback) by David Humphreys
gave 3 stars to: Who's Your City?: How the Creative Economy Is Making Where to Live the Most Important Decision of Your Life (Hardcover) by Richard Florida

book.title: Who's Your City?: How the Creative Economy Is Making Where to Live the Most Important Decision of Your Life

update.body: I think this book is not as revolutionary as the Creative Class but I did appreciate reading the analysis of different cities and rankings. I also think it would do a lot of people good to think about where they what to live in terms of lifestyle provided and ammenities.

update.action_text: gave 3 stars to: The Celestial Hierarchy (Sacred Books #64) by Pseudo-Dionysius the Areopagite
update.body: This is not exactly light reading but for those interested in angelology it is an important canononical source. This book discusses the different orders of angels and their characteristics.

update.action_text: gave 5 stars to: I Had the Strangest Dream...: The Dreamer's Dictionary for the 21st Century (ebook) by Kelly Sullivan Walden

book.title: I Had the Strangest Dream...: The Dreamer's Dictionary for the 21st Century

update.body: I have several dream analysis books and this one is my favorite. It does a great job explaining the different types of dreams and why we dream. The dream dictnary seems right on most of the time for me. I recognize that everyone dreams differently so I am not sure there is a one dream book that f...more...

update.action_text: gave 5 stars to: Angel Numbers (Paperback) by Doreen Virtue
update.body: I loved this book and found it when I started noticing numbers that kept coming up for me over and over again in the strangest ways. It had never occured to me that numbers were significant but I believe differently now. Here is the number experience that got me to notice when numbers appeared in ...more...
